I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
1.  The additional financing of the Bagmati River Basin Improvement Project consolidates the 
achievements  of  the  current  project,1 and  thereby  will  increase  its  impact  with  regard  to 
safeguarding the unique cultural and economic values of the Bagmati River. 
2.  Under the current project, government institutions in charge of basin management were 
strengthened and better aligned with the new federal state constitution of September 2015. Civil 
society  organizations  were  established  and  have  become  active  stakeholders  in  basin 
management. River beautification works have used nature-based solutions and given residents 
renewed appreciation of the Bagmati River. However, these beautification works cover only about 
half of the urban area, and expansion would significantly increase the impact of the works, while 
also incorporating the culturally most significant portion of the river, which has cultural heritage 
buildings that were severely damaged during the 2015 earthquakes. River water availability will 
increase through completion of the Dhap dam under the current project, which will allow targeted 
releases of water during the dry season, but additional work is required to capture and treat to a 
high standard contaminated water for reuse in the main river branch. A flood forecasting and early 
warning system has been developed, but more training is needed in its use, and the system needs 
to be better anchored with institutions in charge of flood protection. 
3.  The additional financing will focus on (i) consolidating of water management institutions, 
including civil society platforms; (ii) expanding river beautification, including the cultural value of 
the riverine environment; (iii) improving water availability during the dry season; and (iv) improving 
and consolidating the flood forecasting and early warning system. 
4.  The additional financing is estimated to cost $78.8 million. The Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) is requested to finance $63.0 million while the government will finance the remaining $15.8 
million. The proposed associated transaction technical assistance (TA) will be financed through 
a grant of $0.60 million. The additional financing and this TA are included in the ADB country 
operation business plan, 2019–2021.2 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
5.  The TA will support capacity building of the Bagmati River basin water management 
institutions  and  focus  on  information  technology  (IT)  applications  that  can  support  basin 
management and strengthen decision making. These IT applications were partially developed 
under the current project, but are incomplete and lack full connectivity and networking; in addition, 
further evolution of basin management policies require adaptation of the information exchange. 
The capacity development is proposed in an associated TA because the tasks are specialized 
and require specific consultant skills; targeted, concentrated specialist inputs; and a well-installed 
IT system and network. A well-established operation and maintenance procedure for the IT 
system needs to be developed and tested for continued smooth operation after project completion. 
Establishing such a system requires demonstrated successful experience with comparable tasks.

C.  Cost and Financing 
7.  The TA is estimated to cost $620,000, of which $600,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s technical assistance special fund (TASF-6). The key expenditure items are listed 
Appendix 1.

3 
8.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
space, workshop venues and other in-kind contributions. The government was informed that 
approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
9.  ADB will administer the TA. The Water and Energy Commission Secretariat will be the 
executing agency for the TA. A steering committee, chaired by the Water and Energy Commission 
Secretariat and including representatives of the Koshi River basin office, the High Powered 
Committee  for  the  Integrated  Development  of  the  Bagmati  Civilization,  the  Department  of 
Hydrology and Meteorology, and relevant local and provincial government representatives will 
guide the project. Disbursement under the TA will be in line with the ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010 as amended from time to time).
